The Elder Cūḷasugandha’s Birth Story
“In this auspicious aeon,
the kinsman of Brahmā, of great fame,
the one named Kassapa by clan,
arose, the best of speakers.
Endowed with the minor marks,
with the thirty-two characteristics,
surrounded by a halo of light,
with a web of radiance spreading out.
Like the moon, he was a source of comfort,
like the sun, he was a source of light,
like a cloud, he was a source of refreshment,
like the ocean, he was a source of qualities.
Like the earth, he was firm in virtue,
like the Himalayas, he was firm in concentration,
like space, he was firm in wisdom,

With a heart full of compassion,

With fame renowned in the world,

The hero is spread with glory,

With an unattached mind everywhere,

The support of all beings,

Unstained by the world,

With the sun and moon for eyes,

Like a ford everywhere,

Like Mount Gandhamādana,

The hero is a source of virtues,🔽like the ocean is a source of jewels;
Like the Sindhu is a source of rivers,

Like a great victorious warrior,
subduing the army of Māra;
Like a universal monarch,
possessing the jewel of the factors of awakening.
With great splendor,
curing the sickness of hatred;
Like a physician, a surgeon,
The one who has removed the dart of views.

The summary:
Bhaddiya, Revata, the elder,
Sīvali, the one with great gains,
Vaṅgīsa, and Nandaka,
Kāḷudāyī, and likewise Ābhaya.
Lomasa, and Vanavaccha,
And fragrant is the tenth.
There are three hundred verses there,
And sixteen more besides.
Now the summary of the vaggas:
The vagga of Kaṇikāra,
The fruit-giver, the grass-giver,
The vagga of Kaccāna, Bhaddiya,
These verses have been counted.
Here there are nine hundred verses,
And four hundred and eighty,
Fifty-six hundred,
The metrical feet have been explained.
Together with the verses of the Udāna,
They make six thousand,
Two hundred and eighteen verses.
